name: 100 Percent Men
blurb - as of 5/21: In case you were concerned there are too many powerful women in the U.S., this bizarre tumblr reminds you of all the men still dancing atop that glass ceiling by listing and connecting their names.

name: 99U
blurb - as of 5/21: This is the place to go if you thought up a business idea (possibly while high) and a few days later still want to make it real. Experts in productivity and creativity write about getting it done.

name: AbandonedNYC
blurb - as of 5/21: One would think that every inch of New York City has been captured before, but this blog uncovers the haunted and lonely corners of the most populous U.S. city.

name: Arts & Letters Daily
blurb - as of 5/21: Pulls and summarizes the best of the artsy pubs you want to read (or pretend to read), like the American Scholar and n+1. It's great as a reading list, or as a crib sheet for the literary set.

name: Artsy
blurb - as of 5/21: Artsy brings the gallery to you, offering a rapidly growing (30K+) collection of high-res artworks from every era and area. Founded in a Princeton dorm room, it's since pulled millions in funding.

name: Atavist
blurb - as of 5/21: This Brooklyn-based online mag reminds us of an old-fashioned glossy, with a sleek design and meaty, storytelling features. Like most old media, it isn't free, but the stories are worth a few bucks.

name: BackBid
blurb - as of 5/21: A welcome new business model in an otherwise dated field, Backbid lets users show the rate they've booked for a hotel and ask other hotels to beat the price.

name: Bad Kids Jokes
blurb - as of 5/21: There’s something endlessly humorous about errant kids’ jokes. Most of them make no sense and poop is a theme, but you'll giggle at this site, which catalogs jokes rejected by a kids' site.

name: Bloesem
blurb - as of 5/21: Malaysia-based Irene Hoofs aims to give "design-conscious parents" ideas for stuff to do with their kids, with a heavy dose of clever and absolutely no Martha Stewart.

name: Brain Pickings
blurb - as of 5/21: With nothing more complicated than a very smart and content-heavy blog, Brooklyn's Maria Popova has built a stalwart following by scraping the web for its most intellectual content.

name: Camera Awesome
blurb - as of 5/21: Awesome features include image stabilization, the ability to focus in one place but have the exposure in another, slow and fast burst shooting, and interval shooting. It's awesome.

name: CR Fashion Book
blurb - as of 5/21: Former French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld gives readers backstage access with videos from fashion shoots and original content that’s as glossy and sexy as the stuff found in the print version.

name: Curisma
blurb - as of 5/21: Curisma knows what gadget you want to buy before you do. Seed it with a few things you like, and it'll spit out some Not Safe for Wallet suggestions from a wide swath of sites.

name: DadWagon
blurb - as of 5/21: Not your father's fatherhood blog: a crew of young NYC journos collect irreverent tips and share (occasionally obscene) stories on the fast-changing job of being a dad, from tantrums to divorce.

name: DailyLit
blurb - as of 5/21: If you've got time for email but not for Emerson, check out DailyLit, which sends a five-minute chunk of belles-lettres to your RSS feed or email every day.
Fact Check: Sends not just to RSS but email. No change made.

name: DatPiff
blurb - as of 5/21: As every hip-hop fan knows, albums are for suckers. The best beats are on the mixtape, and nearly all are here. Register on the site and they can be yours for free.

name: Dinner: A Love Story
blurb - as of 5/21: Jenny Rosenstrach's blog sits at the corner of food and parenting, two things she clearly knows well, alternating between recipes for family dinners and aww-inducing stories of her young kids.
Fact Check: colon, not comma in the title

name: Dlisted
blurb - as of 5/21: The guiltiest of our guilty pleasures is Michael K's LA cousin of Gawker, where some of the meanest people on the Internet discuss celebs and fashion with trademark spite and brilliant turns of phrase.

name: Doom & Gloom From the Tomb
blurb - as of 5/21: Featuring tracks from the likes of The Beach Boys, Fleetwood Mac, and Neil Young, the site is a key resource for live recordings, bootlegs, and unreleased music from the days when rock music mattered.

name: Dots
blurb - as of 5/21: As addictive as Angry Birds, Dots has been downloaded more than 3 million times. It's simple, but not exactly easy, and is great to play when stoned (or so we've heard).
Fact Check: According to http://blog.betaworks.com/, it's 3 million downloads as of May 30. Changed from 2. http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/30/highly-addictive-dots-game-passes-3-million-players/

name: Eat Your Books
blurb - as of 5/21: Lets you make a constantly updated, DIY cookbook thanks to a searchable catalogue of recipes from more than 800,000 cookbooks and across several well-known blogs and food magazines.

name: Elbows
blurb - as of 5/21: Discover what the kids are listening to with this social version of Pitchfork, which aggregates music blogs and ranks what's getting the most buzz.

name: Etymonline
blurb - as of 5/21: Why would you spend any significant time on a comprehensive dictionary of English word origins? Search a few words (especially of the four-letter variety) and just see if you can stop.

name: Evernote Food
blurb - as of 5/21: A place to store and organize all your food favorites and to-do lists, from recipes to restaurant to photos of every plate consumed.
Fact Check: This is true, you can use it as a cookbook - but its more of a tool to document your food experiences -- for the people that take photos of every meal. No change made.

name: Fantastical
blurb - as of 5/21: A calendar app that lets you type in events the way you'd speak them. Tell it to "break up with Candi at 2 on Thursday" and "Break up with Candy" will appear at the appointed hour.

name: FindTheBest
blurb - as of 5/21: Whether you're looking for a smartphone or an industrial drill bit, this site takes consumer reviews into the age of algorithm by sussing out a "smart rating" for products from patchy individual assessments.

name: Flavorwire
blurb - as of 5/21: A solid and offbeat alternative to the exhausting cultural news cycle built around premieres and tabloid obsessions. A good example of this: it recently held a short fiction contest.

name: Foodie
blurb - as of 5/21: Like Epicurious on crack (or artisanal chicken fat), Foodie's a useful and very pretty social network for food lovers who want to up their technique in the kitchen or ogle Michelin-starred dishes.

name: Foodily
blurb - as of 5/21: Want a paleo-friendly recipe that uses artichoke hearts? Foodily’s here for you, with an archive of more than 2 million recipes, social sharing, and nutritional rundowns.

name: Foodspotting
blurb - as of 5/21: Foodspotting goes deeper than Yelp by letting you see photos of actual food, submitted by those people you see taking pictures of their food, at local restaurants.

name: Futility Closet
blurb - as of 5/21: Greg Ross collects what he calls "compendious amusements"--weird anecdotes and fun facts of the day with a decidedly nerdy remit. Perfect if you've got a brainy cocktail party to impress.

name: GeoGuesser
blurb - as of 5/21: If you love geography and competition (and who doesn't?), this one's for you. Accrue wins by guessing where in the world a particular Google Street View is. The closer you get, the smarter you are. Obviously.

name: Grubwithus
blurb - as of 5/21: If OkCupid, Meetup, and Chowhound all had a baby together it might look like this: Site lets you set up dinners with groups of random strangers who share your interests, your taste in food, or both.
Fact Check: Grubwithus is one word. OkCupid is one word.

name: Hacker News
blurb - as of 5/21: Y Combinator's startup whiz Paul Graham brings you a Reddit clone with more positive vibes (you can only vote stuff up, not down) and a community with a pronounced tech focus.

name: HitFix
blurb - as of 5/21: Home to respected TV critic Alan Sepinwall, HitFix is a destination for entertainment junkies who debate the finer points of the industry but have no taste for gossip.

name: Houzz
blurb - as of 5/21: A Better Homes for the Internet age. Houzz's cool interactive features get you home design tips customized for you. Its popular iPad app, with 6 million downloads, is handy for redecorating in situ.

name: I Love Charts
blurb - as of 5/21: We love charts, too. On Jason Oberholtzer and Cody Westphal’s Tumblr, find charts like “How Much We Cried” during Toy Story 3. Endless entertainment/education/timesuck.

name: Iconic Photos
blurb - as of 5/21: Alex Selwyn-Holmes posts haunting, iconic photos that tell a story about a moment in history, and how photography captured it.

name: Into The Gloss
blurb - as of 5/21: It’s one of the newest sites for beauty coverage, but it may be the best. A shiny, straightforward design features beauty insights and tricks from fashion world A-listers, plus an easy click-through-to-buy option.

name: Lil Bub
blurb - as of 5/21: Not too much to get here, just tons of photos of an odd-looking cat with a joyful, wide-eyed gaze. Fans of Lil Bub, the star of a Tribeca-winning documentary, can buy his book and follow him online.

name: Machinarium
blurb - as of 5/21: In this beautiful puzzle game, you're an adorable robot using logic and clues to get from one place to the next. It's hard but approachable.

name: Maddie on Things
blurb - as of 5/21: Maddie is as calm and photogenic as a dog can get. Owner Theron Humphrey started photographing his beloved dog balancing on everything from fire hydrants to basketball hoops, and the results are epic.
Fact Check: Maddie's balancing on the hoop, not the net.

name: Makers
blurb - as of 5/21: A collection of video interviews and stories from kick-ass women leaders, from Ruth Bader Ginsburg to Ellen DeGeneres, who talk lifestyle and leadership.

name: Me & My Shadow
blurb - as of 5/21: Lets you figure out what sort of data footprint is left by your devices and Internet access points so you can see how your digital habits affect your privacy. Good start for eluding the NSA.

name: Medium
blurb - as of 5/21: When the guy behind Twitter tries a new social-network thing, we take notice. The point of Evan Williams’s Medium, in an era of shameless click-bait, is proving survival on good content alone is possible.

name: Menswear Dog
blurb - as of 5/21: Yet another dog blog, but one with some serious style. David Fung and Yena Kim dress their shiba inu in Fung’s clothes—and not only are the poses enthusiastic, but the menswear suggestions are solid.

name: Moda Operandi
blurb - as of 5/21: From Vogue Contributing Editor Lauren Santo Domingo, the beautifully-designed Moda Operandi lets users pre-order designer collections straight from the runway.
Fact Check: Changed "From ex-Vogue editor" to "From Vogue contributing editor." she's still there.
Fact Check comments: Capped Contrib Editor, since it's a title, then. LS

name: Momfilter
blurb - as of 5/21: Momfilter picked up the ball when Cookie, the glossy for with-it parents, shut in 2009, and brims with the same deft and practical ideas for fashion, food and other facets of modern childrearing.

name: Nah Right
blurb - as of 5/21: One of the most actively updated places on the Internet for new rap videos, industry gossip, and remixes. The sheer volume of news makes Nah Right something of a politico of rap sites.

name: Newsmap
blurb - as of 5/21: So weird yet so alluring, the site constantly updates and arranges headlines from Google News based on what's trending, piecing them together into a "treemap" that keeps related material together.

name: NPR's The Picture Show
blurb - as of 5/21: A feed of breathtaking photos and interesting stories from all over the world, updated daily by one of NPR's multimedia reporter-producers.

name: Of a Kind
blurb - as of 5/21: Subscribers to Of a Kind get daily access to designer outfits so cool that very few copies of them exist.
Fact Check: Changed from "One of a Kind" to "Of a Kind"

name: PaperKarma
blurb - as of 5/21: Gets rid of junk mail--actual mail, as in paper, the stuff that the mailman delivers. Snap a photo of the sender's address and he'll get a cease-and-desist letter of his own.

name: Parent Hacks
blurb - as of 5/21: A minimalist, judgment-free collection of creative shortcuts for simplifying and economizing life with kids.

name: PolitiFact
blurb - as of 5/21: The ultimate politcal debunker, Politifact reporters check the veracity of statements made every day by congressmen, mayors, the president, and more, and then rates them on a truth scale.

name: Prison Photography
blurb - as of 5/21: A global perspective on the gritty and honest reality of incarceration, told through photographs, interviews, and commentary.

name: Public Books
blurb - as of 5/21: A monthly compendium of meaty book writing. Pieces are long—expect at least 1,000 words written by professors—and designed to cater to seriously curious readers.

name: Put This On
blurb - as of 5/21: Put This On is one of the web's most useful men's clothing sites, with plentiful and generous tutorials for the sartorially clueless.

name: Reddit Politics
blurb - as of 5/21: Skip the cat gifs and privacy rants and go straight to Reddit's politics page for informed, democratized threads on Rand Paul's marijuana approach and the growing inequality in America.

name: Sabato's Crystal Ball
blurb - as of 5/21: Covering every gubernatorial and Senate race, and every tight one in the House, Sabato and his colleagues at the University of Virginia's Center for Politics have proven they can separate the signal from the noise.

name: Shoptiques
blurb - as of 5/21: Love boutiques but hate getting there? Shoptiques brings them to you. The site has 100 shops and will double that by July, says founder and CEO Olga Vidisheva.

name: The Skeptic's Dictionary
blurb - as of 5/21: An exhaustive compendium of medical quackery, fraud, paranormal mumbo-jumbo and all flavors of pseudoscience. Delightful to browse, almost like a terrible WebMD.
Fact Check: Site Actually named "The Skeptic's Dictionary." No change made.

name: Small Demons
blurb - as of 5/21: This interactive literary encyclopedia connects the books you love based on the people, places and things they contain. Browse all the novels that mention Buddha or spaghetti, or make your own lists.

name: Switchcam
blurb - as of 5/21: Not something we knew we needed, but now that it's here, we admit it's cool: suture your videos to others' from the same event, whether a BBQ or a concert, to create one video of a whole crowd's experience.

name: Taegan Goddard's Political Wire
blurb - as of 5/21: One of the first political websites is still the best. If you read nothing but Political Wire on the day's developments in D.C. and elsewhere, you'll know just about everything that's informing the national conversation.

name: The Classical
blurb - as of 5/21: A scrappier Deadspin, the Classical features a roster of America's best young sportswriters and delivers a one-two punch of superb writing and oddball topics.

name: The Orchestra
blurb - as of 5/21: Follow along with a synchronized score, switch between instruments, and learn more about music than you would sitting in an actual symphony hall (caveat: it eats up 2 gigs of space).

name: The RealReal
blurb - as of 5/21: The best-kept secret of anyone with a well-endowed closet. Sellers get up to 70 percent of the proceeds after the site raids their wardrobes.

name: The Selby
blurb - as of 5/21: Want to sneak into celebrities' houses and peek around? Photographer Todd Selby works his connections with famous friends to bring you neat, and often surprising, snaps of their cribs.

name: The Spectator Archive
blurb - as of 5/21: One of the best English-language magazines in the world has undertaken the unenviable task of digitizing every issue since it began publishing in 1828. And all 1.5 million pages are, as of now, available for free.

name: The Waste Land
blurb - as of 5/21: Brings alive T.S. Eliot's masterpiece with a series of interactive features, from audio readings to expert commentary. It's a gorgeous way to use new tech to experience old art.
Fact Check: Capitalized Title/Added e to end of Literature

name: The Weight of Objects
blurb - as of 5/21: Probably the most sophisticated Tumblr here, this is an NYC editor and photographer duo's portrait project. Each entry features a photo of a person and another of a treasured but ordinary possession.

name: TouchOfModern
blurb - as of 5/21: ToMo to the initiated, this flash site sends its design-oriented members deals on unique furnishings and equipment, which its fans say beat out competitors like Gilt and Hautelook aesthetically.

name: TourWrist
blurb - as of 5/21: Photo sharing in 360 degrees: users upload beautiful and occasionally vertigo-inducing panoramas of the Grand Canyon, the Great Wall, and other vistas you might want to scroll around.

name: Turntable
blurb - as of 5/21: Be a DJ without leaving your basement by sharing music live with other fans in user-made virtual clubs. Or just pop in and listen.

name: Valleywag
blurb - as of 5/21: The ruthless Silicon Valley gossip rag shut down four years ago, only to reignite this year as the go-to source for leaked sex tapes, prototype photos, and the juicy rumors that fuel obsessive techies.

name: Wantful
blurb - as of 5/21: Like MadLibs for gift-giving: you fill in some blanks about the recipient and your budget, and Wantful puts together a gift package.

name: We the People
blurb - as of 5/21: It's where citizens can petition the president directly, which means it's a huge archive of the things in America that actually garner Obama's attention (i.e. building a Death Star). An endlessly fascinating read.

name: Weigel
blurb - as of 5/21: Like Lay's potato chips, Weigel's posts on Slate are tasty, salty, and addictive. Same goes for his Twitter feed, by the way.

name: Wondermind
blurb - as of 5/21: The UK's Tate Gallery hosts this sometimes trippy and always edifying guide to the mind for kids, with Alice in Wonderland as the thematic backdrop to its games and videos.

name: You Are Blind
blurb - as of 5/21: This unexpectedly fascinating Russian site gives sighted browsers the unsettling experience of being blind, by offering a very complex and very dark simulation of moving around in darkness.

name: Unz.org
blurb - as of 5/21: Created by businessman and political activist Ron Unz, Unz.org houses an invaluable archive of well-known and long-forgotten political and cultural magazines--scanned, searchable, and available for download.
